In reading many of the insightful comments/explanations below that provide very thoughtful inside/outside probabilities, many were authored prior to a significant global COVID outbreak. A base rate informed by pre-COVID attack trends between the US & Iran, IMO, must be modified to reflect the COVID context. In which direction? Let's look at the domestic contexts for action (inside view): Iran: significant COVID infection scandal; poor public opinion of govt; increasingly diminished resources thanks to sanctions, COVID, and oil market crash; continued anti-American rhetoric and warnings; public still smarting over Soleimani death US: bellicose POTUS that responded violently to Iranian provocations/attacks previously; almost 1 million COVID cases; upcoming presidential election; devastated economy; tweets for US Navy to destroy Iranian ships that harass them. These factors could tip the balance in either way (attack to distract, rally around the flag or don't attack bc it exacerbates uncertainty too much). I lean toward the latter--the risk of exacerbating uncertainty will be too high for both governments during COVID, but I think the inside view is mostly indeterminate. The outside view should consider the average rate of attack annually (monthly?) between the US and Iran, the targets of those attacks (are national forces postured at the targets), the accuracy of those attacks (probability of killing a national force) as a rough start point. Based on the calculations of these probabilities by smart people below, I'd say the general base rate is very low, 10-20%, but is elevated in 2020 given the number of attacks that have taken place within the last six months and the momentum this has generated, so I bump to the 20-30% probability.

It's been approximately 46 days since the U.S. strike that killed Soleimani. The Islamic Republic News Agency barely mentions Soleimani - it lacks the front page fiery anti-U.S. rhetoric that would likely characterize an Iranian state-sanctioned response. Similarly, the Official Website of the President of the Islamic Republic of Iran does not mention Soleimani and the Official website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Islamic Republic of Iran makes only one front-page mention of Soleimani (dating from a 11 February 2020 article). Moreover, major U.S. news agencies have not reported any prominent statements emanating from Iran since late January. Further, despite the deployment of a 4,000-member Brigade from the 82nd Airborne, and some minor force protection enhancements in the region, the U.S. has not made public any major deployments of forces in the wake of the strike (e.g., carrier battle groups, Marine Expeditionary Forces, strike aircraft, Tomahawk-capable submarines, etc.). Likewise, open source intelligence has not reported any concerning Iranian troop or strategic asset movements (deployment of ballistic missile batteries to firing points, movement of troops to assembly areas, etc.). As such, it stands to reason that any retaliatory measures by Iran would have been initiated while the event was still fresh in the national memory. Either Iran is still in a "wait and see" period of assessing U.S. strategic moves while planning long-range escalatory measures, or Iran has accepted the strike as U.S. signaling that it had crossed a U.S. "red line," and intends to back down any provocative actions for the foreseeable future. This suggests to me that Iran will likely "lay low" for a while, until such time it decides to incrementally test the boundaries of U.S. strategic action, which in my opinion, will not be for several more months. Accordingly, at this point I am assessing the probability of a lethal confrontation involving at least one fatality between the military forces of either side in the airspace, seaspace, or landspace of Iran as low and very unlikely. Since there are still roughly 10-11 months remaining on the question, however, I'm leaving a margin open to the possibility.
